transcription.text: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria. The film broke new artistic ground by using special effects to re-create the eruption of Mount Etna and the naval battle of Syracuse, but its biggest legacy is the ‘Cabiria’ shot: the tracking shot. Pastrone mounted a camera on a dolly to trail the action in a scene, and this new technique was quickly adopted by filmmakers at the time.

Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks like multiple exposures, split-screens, time-lapse photography, dissolves and hand-colouring. He even accidentally invented the jump cut when his camera jammed. Between 1896 and 1913, Méliès directed over 500 films. He described them as “little abracadabras” and they were truly magical, inviting audiences on A Trip to the Moon (1902), into The Kingdom of Fairies (1903) and to enjoy a chorus of decapitated heads.

work.title: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)

The Samsung Gear VR is a virtual reality head-mounted display mount developed by Samsung Electronics, in collaboration with Oculus VR, and manufactured by Samsung. The headset was released on November 27, 2015.

When in use, a compatible Samsung Galaxy device acts as the headset's display and processor, while the Gear VR unit itself acts as the controller, which contains the field of view, as well as a custom inertial measurement unit, or IMU, for rotational tracking, which connects to the smartphone via USB-C or micro-USB. The Gear VR headset also includes a touchpad and back button on the side, as well as a proximity sensor to detect when the headset is on.

The Gear VR was first announced on September 3, 2014. To allow developers to create content for the Gear VR and to allow VR and technology enthusiasts to get early access to the technology, Samsung had released two innovator editions of the Gear VR before the consumer version.

The 1980s saw Indigenous activism and Black Power gain prominence in mainstream screen and pop culture, with activist Gary Foley appearing in the cult classic Dogs in Space (1986) and the family favourite TV show A Country Practice (1989). These pop culture moments, although brief, arguably reached a much wider audience than protests and demonstrate the power of screen culture as a tool of activism, social change and the ongoing struggle for Indigenous Rights.

work.title: Gary Foley on the set of Dogs in Space in Melbourne

transcription.text: A compliation of moments from various 'home movies' in the ACMI Collection.

For 40 days, @thinfrog posted videos showing frog spawn being gathered from various waterways and placed in his backyard pond to create a 'frog army', which soon took over his and his neighbours' gardens. Four million views followed, some revelling in the squelchy horror, others outraged by his ego tripping, plague fantasies and environmental irresponsibility. However others noted that the footage had been sourced from a variety of existing docos and news stories: a hoax of biblical proportions.

Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). From a technologically advanced but nightmarish future to mad scientists and the first robot in a feature, Metropolis has influenced so much of what we see on-screen today. At two hours and 33 minutes, it was also one of the longest films ever made at the time. Critics were sceptical at first, but it’s now considered groundbreaking, particularly for its production design and costumes. Those two elements have inspired C-3PO in Star Wars, Kylie Minogue’s robotic stage costumes and the futuristic city in Blade Runner. If that wasn't enough, Lang's seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.

This coloured slide is an advertisement for the film 'Four Jills in a Jeep' featuring Kay Francis, Carole Landis, Martha Raye, and Mitzi Mayfair distributed by 20th Century Fox Pictures. Three pieces of cream tape have been adhered to the top edge to cover cinema session details. Kay Francis, Carole Landis, Martha Raye, and Mitzi Mayfair as themselves, re-enacting their USO tour of Europe and North Africa during World War II.
